cs.umass.edu.myactivitiestoolkit.view.fragments

Class ExerciseFragment

  • java.lang.Object
    • Fragment
      • cs.umass.edu.myactivitiestoolkit.view.fragments.ExerciseFragment

  • public class ExerciseFragment
extends Fragment
    Fragment which visualizes the 3-axis accelerometer signal, displays the step count estimates and current activity to the user and allows the user to interact with the AccelerometerService.

    ASSIGNMENT 0 (Data Collection & Visualization) : In this assignment, you will display and visualize the accelerometer readings and send the data to the server. The framework is there for you; you only need to make the calls in the AccelerometerService to communicate the data.

    ASSIGNMENT 1 (Step Detection) : In this assignment, you will detect steps using the accelerometer sensor. You will design both a local step detection algorithm and a server-side (Python) step detection algorithm. Your algorithm should look for peaks and account for the fact that humans generally take steps every 0.5 - 2.0 seconds. Your local and server-side algorithms may be functionally identical, or you may choose to take advantage of other Python tools/libraries to improve performance.

    ASSIGNMENT 2 (Activity Detection) : In this assignment, you will classify the user's activity based on the accelerometer data. The only modification you should make to the mobile app is to register a listener which will parse the activity from the acquired JSONObject and update the UI. The real work, that is your activity detection algorithm, will be running in the Python script and acquiring data via the server.
    See Also:
    AccelerometerService, XYPlot, Fragment

      • onStart

        public void onStart()
        When the fragment starts, register a receiver to receive messages from the AccelerometerService. The intent filter defines messages we are interested in receiving.

        We would like to receive sensor data, so we specify Constants.ACTION#BROADCAST_ACCELEROMETER_DATA. We would also like to receive step count updates, so include Constants.ACTION#BROADCAST_ANDROID_STEP_COUNT and Constants.ACTION#BROADCAST_LOCAL_STEP_COUNT.

        To optionally display the peak values you compute, include Constants.ACTION#BROADCAST_ACCELEROMETER_PEAK.

        Lastly to update the state of the accelerometer switch properly, we listen for additional messages, using Constants.ACTION#BROADCAST_MESSAGE.
        See Also:
        Constants.ACTION, IntentFilter, LocalBroadcastManager, receiver

      • onStop

        public void onStop()
        When the fragment stops, e.g. the user closes the application or opens a new activity, then we should unregister the receiver.
